manuscript.title: Tehzibu'l-Luga (Tahdhīb al-Lugha / تهذيب اللغة)
manuscript.author: Ebû Mansûr Muhammed ibn Ahmed el-Ezherî (Abū Manṣūr Muḥammad ibn Aḥmad al-Azharī, d. 980 CE / 370 AH)

paper_decoration.summary: Gold-sprinkled paper (zerefşân) is attested on the endpapers. The YEK catalogue records 'zerefşân kâğıtla kaplanmıştır': the endpapers are covered/lined with gold-sprinkled paper, which serves as the ground for an elaborate painted floral decoration (şükûfe) in naturalistic Ottoman style. Only the endpaper opening (p001) was visually examined; interior text folios were not inspected, so it cannot be confirmed whether zerefşân extends to the text paper stock. On present evidence, zerefşân is recorded as an endpaper feature only. This use of luxury decorated paper as endpaper lining is consistent with well-attested Ottoman binding practice, in which gold-sprinkled, marbled, or painted sheets are applied to inside covers as doublure linings.

paper_decoration.details: The screenshot shows what appears to be the inside front and back covers (or endpaper opening) of the manuscript, featuring elaborate floral painted decoration. Both surfaces display dense naturalistic floral compositions with large rose and peony sprays, leaves, stems, and smaller blossoms in pink, red, green, and cream tones. The painting style shows naturalistic Ottoman flower painting (şükûfe) with a generous, spreading composition. The catalogue entry states 'zerefsan kagitla kaplanmistir': the endpapers are covered/lined with gold-sprinkled paper. The zerefşân serves as the ground layer beneath or between the floral painting, though at this resolution the gold particles cannot be individually distinguished from the painted surface. The floral endpaper decoration is a well-attested Ottoman binding tradition, where decorated papers (gold-sprinkled, marbled, or painted) are used to line the inside covers. The quality and density of the floral painting suggest high-level production. Critically, only the endpaper opening was examined; the main text paper stock should be checked separately to determine whether zerefşân extends beyond the endpapers.

style_attribution.workshop: Naturalistic floral painting style consistent with 18th-century Ottoman şükûfe traditions; could be original binding production or a later re-endpapering
style_attribution.justification: The naturalistic, spreading floral compositions with large roses and peonies on endpapers are characteristic of the 18th-century Ottoman decorative tradition. This style of painted endpaper became increasingly popular from the late 17th century onward, with particularly fine examples in 18th-century bindings. Endpapers can, however, be replaced during rebinding, so the floral decoration may not be coeval with the manuscript text (Tahdhīb al-Lugha is a classical 10th-century Arabic lexicographic work). The zerefşân ground beneath the painting adds a layer of luxury consistent with high-quality Ottoman binding practice. The Veliyyuddin Efendi collection was established in 1769 CE, providing a terminus ante quem for at least the acquisition of this volume.

folio_analyses.condition_notes: The floral painted endpapers appear well-preserved with vivid colours intact. Some slight wear or rubbing may be visible at the edges where the endpapers meet the binding boards. Overall condition appears good.
folio_analyses.analysis_limitations: Image is a YEK viewer screenshot at moderate resolution. The floral painting is clearly visible and identifiable, but the zerefşân ground layer beneath it cannot be independently verified at this resolution — gold particles are likely obscured by the overlying paint. The catalogue's specification of 'zerefsan kagitla kaplanmistir' is the primary evidence for the gold-sprinkled substrate. It is also possible that 'zerefsan' in the catalogue refers to gold elements within the floral painting rather than a separately prepared sprinkled ground, though the phrasing 'kagitla kaplanmistir' (covered/lined with paper) strongly suggests prepared zerefşân paper sheets were applied. Only the endpaper opening was examined; the main text pages were not checked.

bibliography.relevance: Detailed technical study of Islamic bookbinding methods, including the use of decorated papers (marbled, gold-sprinkled, painted) as doublure and endpaper materials. Directly relevant to the endpaper binding context of this manuscript.

provenance.donor: Veliyyuddin Efendi (likely Mehmed Veliyyüddin Efendi, şeyhülislam, d. 1768)
provenance.waqf: Veliyyuddin Efendi Vakfı (waqf collection established c. 1769 CE)
provenance.notes: The Veliyyuddin Efendi Kütüphanesi was established in Istanbul as a pious foundation (vakıf) library. The collection shelfmark V 3099 places this manuscript within the Veliyyuddin Efendi collection. The YEK internal record ID is 547179. The terminus ante quem for acquisition is the foundation date of the library (c. 1769 CE), though the manuscript and its binding may be earlier. The donor is traditionally identified as Mehmed Veliyyüddin Efendi, who served as şeyhülislam (chief Ottoman religious jurist); the collection was endowed after his death and now forms part of the Süleymaniye Kütüphanesi holdings accessible via the YEK portal.
